| The Duke Of York's Library is to be sold by
Sotheby, and to our utter astonishment contains
above forty thousand volumes, including, besides
number of valuable illustrated books Of ancient
days, nearly every publication entered at Station
er's Hall, and every novel and pamphlet printed
IN the United Kingdom during the last forty years.
In the library is valuable and extensive collec-
ton of maps and charts.


Mr.. Weilesley and his Children.--In the Court
of Chancery, in London, on the 10th of January,
the arguments in the case were renewed The
Attorney General said, that one ground against
MIR. W. having the care Of his children was, that
he had deliberately sworn in his afidavits to what
was not true. Mr.. w. when his feelings were
wounded during the discussion. frequently inter-
rupted the proceedings, and at one time frantcly
exclaimed to the Lord Chanceor-ss For Gods
sake, (said hey humbly ask your judgment one
way or other" The Lord Chancellor pontedy
reproved this expression, stating that, when he
heard counsel, he should give his Judgment when
and in what way he pleased. 1t was then stated
by counsel, that, at the time when MIR. Wellesley
swore he had not any criminal conversation with
Mrs. Bgh, he was living with her under feian-
ed name, in London; that she, in the disguise of
his servant, often met him abroad, and that he gen.
orally attended her home at two or three in the
morning 1t was further stated that the afidavits,
on which was found II the present application,
showed such degree Of proiligacy, debauchery,
and fasshood, in Mr.. w. as rendered him in
competent to have the education Of his children.
The hearing was adjourned on Wednesday, when
other counsel spoke against Mr.. Wellesley's
claims. Mr.. Hunt then, in long speech, depre-
Gated the system Of calumniating Mr.. Wellesley
in the newspapers, and said that, in Mr. WIS.
connexion with Mrs. Bligh, that gentleman had
made many struggles to terminate the connexion,
but they had been frustrated by the perseverance
with which Mrs. B. followed him from place to
place. The case was adjourned to the following
day.


When Mr.. Wellesley left the Court, he was
assaed by hisscs, and cries Of Shame," from
the persons assembled, who forced him to take re
fuge in some chambers in the great square. Some
of them cried out, "You have murdered youi
wife Pc You ought to be hanged !"

The Senate of Indiana have adopted resolutions
approving Of the conduct of the administration, IN

Indinna.-The Legislature Of this State diourn
ed on Saturday. 9th ult. after session OF eight
weeks. The Indianapolis Gazette of the ed inst
says. "thc joint resolution from the Senate approx
ing the measures Of the Administration Of the Gen.
eral Government, was laid on the table the House
on the 24th ult by vote of3O to "a, Il may be
said from this vote, that majority Of the House
were opposed to the Administration; but such i
not the case. Several gentlemen who voted fol
laying the resolution on the table. expressed them
selves as being favorable TO the Administration, ant
would give their support to MIR. Adams tor ths
next President, but were Of opinion their constiu
cnts had sent them to the Legislature to express
such opinions. The resolution passed the Senate
almost unanimously"

Al Baltimore, on Friday.

Mammoth Of Wanmoths.-A Columbus (Ohio)
paper states that boat which had arrived al Steu
benville, had on board the bones of nondescript
animal, one of which was 90 feet in length, 8 in
width, and weighed upwards of 1900 lbs. The back
bone 16 inches in diameter, and the ribs feet
in length. 1t is calculated from the size Of the
bones that the animal, when living, must have been
about so feet in length 90 to &c feet in width, and
about 90 feet in height; and it must have weighed
at least go tons. These bones were found near
the Mississippi river, iii Louisiana, and form the
greatest natural curiosity ever beheld. This ami
NAL must have as far transcribed the mammoth
in size, as the mammoth common dog.

That every Preacher in this Conference be requested to
make collection the 4h of July next in aid of the
American Colonization Society That they dscountenance
by precept and example, the perncous but too common
practice Of buying or dealing in Lottery Tickets. The
first Fridays May and October next were set apart to be
observed days Of Fasting and Prayer in the bounds
this Conference. Constitution for the contemplated
College to be established in the Virginia Conference wa
adopted and each Minister authorised his exerton
in obtaining subscribers for this purpose.


During the session of the Conference town has beer
alive with VISITORS which this interesting occasion has call
ed together Crowded and attentive congregations have
constantly been present public service by day and night
On Sunday last the Ordination of Deacons and Elders took
place the Methodist church. Bishops Roberts and Sout
officiating and the puIps of the other denominations
having been politely offered they were occupied by ths
Methodist clergy on the same day.

ELECTION.

F4rs.-The extensive four story Dry Goods Store, No
49, Maiden Lane, New York, occupied by John Bowen
Co was nearly destroyed by fire Thursday afternoon
last. Several adjoining buildings considerably dam
aged. Two OF the fremen much injured by the
falling of cornce and gutter, that they survived the ac
cident but few hours.

The endorsements into which the house of
Lippincotts, of Philadelphia, was brought by the
heavy advances which it, in good faith. made on
certain quantities Of teas was matter OF notori-
ETY. throughout the country, and even became the
subject of paragraphs in the London and other
European Journals. The successful issue to which
it has brought its affairs, ought to be extensive
y known and we doubt not the communication
Of the fact will afford unmixed satisfaction to the
numerous friends and correspondents of this
house, both at home and abroad. During the past
year it has paid debts to the amount OF seven hun
dred thousand dollars; and it has very extern
sive solid capital remaining, quite as much as IT
can employ to advantage in business, in the pre-
sent state Of trade. An old merchant has told US
that he never knew of another house which, when
its scheme of commercial operations was in like
manner deranged, had been able to discharge so
large an amount of demands in so short period
Few commercial houses would indeed have sustain
ed such shock, and have brought their affairs to
such an issue, when deprived for so long time of
the use of great proportion of their circulating
capital. Ph't. dazeffe.

"The Woolen Bill is finally decided. The mo-
ton to lay it on the table, was carried by the cast
ino vote Of the vice president-to him therefore
are the manufacturers and the agriculturists to
place the disappointment of their hopes. The dis
ciplined opposition, from the earliest moment Of
the introduction of the bill, brought all their arts
to bear against it. BY proctastination and motions
Of recommitment; and Ir kramer, OF Pa was, to
our modification made TO p,av the part Of buffuon,
and speak against time r.-,sle,srs, lngham. Steven
son and others have much to answer for, for unit
ing against this measure which was SO much in
harmony with our past policy and 50 essential to
our prosperity. The time it seems, has arrived,
in this country, when all our great national mea-
sures are to be disposed Of as they shalt affect the
next Presidential election The south must be
propitiated by the Jackson men, even at the pros
traton of those measures from which we anticipated
so much and such lasting advantages. Messrs.
Stewart, Lawrence and Tell, have deserved well
Of our statc By their active participation in debate:
Others Of willing to engage in it if neces.
sary.


How long shall we be trammelled by the arts of
designing mcn. | was for Jackson, bat may public
confidence De withdrawn from Inc whenever con-
set to forego the interest of my constituents and
state, to elevate any individual to office. will
tell you, and MY state hereafter, the appeals that

are open and verify believe now that General jack
son is mainly advocated by ambitious men, who
would sacrifice the cause of domestic industry and
Internal Improvement, it it should be thought ne
cessary for the election Of Mr. Calhoun; at the
termination of General Jackson's four years. do
hope and trust that all the papers favorable to these
great interests will correctly state these facts"


Philadelphia Press.


Washington. March 6.-Thc proceedings Of
the late Congress, and particularly of its Second
Session, are full of instruction. The grounds
upon which the Opposition are to take their stand
have been distinctly avowed Neutrality is no
longer lustifable. We must either sacrifice our
principles. or we must attach ourselves to one
party or the other. Avowing, from the moment
we established our press that we believed It to be
not only the right, but the duty, Of General Coy
ernment to prosecute Internal improvements and
to foster and encourage the Manufacturing inter
ests Of our Country, never can and never
will combine with party whose avowed prln
ciple is hostility to measures conducive to the gen
eral 'UeIfure, and such as will render us in time
war, at least for the necessaries of life, indepen
dent Of every nation upon the earth.--JournM
EXTRACT OF A LETTER, DATED

Atkinson has been apprehended for passing counterfeit
Gve dollar notes Of the Marine Bank. He succeeded in
passing Of them Friday, in the neghborhood Of
Howard and Lexington streets.


New York, March 5.
The Greeks-We have the satisfaction that
Mr.. p Miller of Vermont, who has been volunteer in
the Greek service for two years. arrived in this city last
evening He is full of ardor and enthusiasm for the
and win 60 Immediately the Agent of the Greek
Committee, in the ship Chancellor, which is loading
second ship will be despatched in short time in charge
Of Lieut.. Carpenter Of the Navy The Greek available
fund already received by the committee in this city, amounts
to $4,000 The subscriptions in kind amount TO upwards
Of 1000 lars So that there will be no difficulty
in sending two ships the purchases be
advantageousy made, and the ships can be freghted.


Neru York, March TO-
The Greek Supply Ship.-The elegant ship Chancellor
Capt. Baker. hauled out in the stream yesterday, and viii
probably sail to-day with provisions, &C. for the Greeks
Mr. Miller, of Vermont who three years in Greece
and eighteen montha active services goes out in the
sell He will have the charge of the supplies and pay at
enon their distribution The cargo said to be worth
about S18,0o0 including the freight and insurance. which
have been paid consists principally Of corn meal -four
rice and the like articles.

full articles.headline: ADMINISTRATION IN INDIANA.
full articles.article:
The Senate of Indiana have adopted resolutions
approving Of the conduct of the administration, IN
relation to internal Improvements and the Panama
Mission.


Also, general resolution in the following words


Resolrsd, that our confidence in the President
OF the United States, and the members OF his cabi'
net, is based upon their public conduct, and Is
cheerfully accorded them by this general assembly


These resolutions passed the Senate is to @


Indinna.-The Legislature Of this State diourn
ed on Saturday. 9th ult. after session OF eight
weeks. The Indianapolis Gazette of the ed inst
says. "thc joint resolution from the Senate approx
ing the measures Of the Administration Of the Gen.
eral Government, was laid on the table the House
on the 24th ult by vote of3O to "a, Il may be
said from this vote, that majority Of the House
were opposed to the Administration; but such i
not the case. Several gentlemen who voted fol
laying the resolution on the table. expressed them
selves as being favorable TO the Administration, ant
would give their support to MIR. Adams tor ths
next President, but were Of opinion their constiu
cnts had sent them to the Legislature to express
such opinions. The resolution passed the Senate
almost unanimously"

full articles.article:
John Williams, Esq Of Ptmsson, Worcester, cnl
tyates strawberries small ridges Of earth running north
and south, about inches above the level Of tie gounds
planting the strawberries the top, aud laying plain tes
each side Of the ridge. He finds the produce earlier,
abundant, and better favored than plants grown
the fiat ground. The fat tiles retain the moisture, pro-
the rpsnng Of the fruit, and keep ii free from dirt
after heavy showers Of raino Gard Mug

full articles.article:
Mammoth Of Wanmoths.-A Columbus (Ohio)
paper states that boat which had arrived al Steu
benville, had on board the bones of nondescript
animal, one of which was 90 feet in length, 8 in
width, and weighed upwards of 1900 lbs. The back
bone 16 inches in diameter, and the ribs feet
in length. 1t is calculated from the size Of the
bones that the animal, when living, must have been
about so feet in length 90 to &c feet in width, and
about 90 feet in height; and it must have weighed
at least go tons. These bones were found near
the Mississippi river, iii Louisiana, and form the
greatest natural curiosity ever beheld. This ami
NAL must have as far transcribed the mammoth
in size, as the mammoth common dog.

The Br. brig Sir T Duckworth loaded with corn, hay.
and cattle, bound Bermuda in attempting TO beat
Of the East River yesterday morning capszed eff White
hall slip. The saved Ave of the oxen swan
to Governors Island and got shore Gone is sup
posed will not live,) and brought into Whitehall
slip. The brig has been towed to Brooklyn by the steam
boat Nautilus The cargo is damaged.


Thirty-one head of fat cattle were drowned.

full articles.headline: VIRGINIA CONFERENCE
full articles.article:
0thc Methodist Episcopal Church held in Petersburg. Febru


arg, 1897


Numbers in Society last year. Whites 2l725-Colored
7847. Present year, Whites 2280l-Colored 1857 The
increase of Members this year has been 17951l persons
we're regularly recommended and admitted trial to the
Minisry--8 Ordained Deacons, and 8 Elders Among
other resolutions the Conference passed the following


That every Preacher in this Conference be requested to
make collection the 4h of July next in aid of the
American Colonization Society That they dscountenance
by precept and example, the perncous but too common
practice Of buying or dealing in Lottery Tickets. The
first Fridays May and October next were set apart to be
observed days Of Fasting and Prayer in the bounds
this Conference. Constitution for the contemplated
College to be established in the Virginia Conference wa
adopted and each Minister authorised his exerton
in obtaining subscribers for this purpose.


During the session of the Conference town has beer
alive with VISITORS which this interesting occasion has call
ed together Crowded and attentive congregations have
constantly been present public service by day and night
On Sunday last the Ordination of Deacons and Elders took
place the Methodist church. Bishops Roberts and Sout
officiating and the puIps of the other denominations
having been politely offered they were occupied by ths
Methodist clergy on the same day.


One Of the last Of this body unanimous vote
Of thanks citizens for their hospitality and attention
members-to the Cergymen of the other denomna
ons for the of their pulpsand to the Masonic Fra
ernity, for the occupancy of their commodious room
Petersburg InteMgenrer.

F4rs.-The extensive four story Dry Goods Store, No
49, Maiden Lane, New York, occupied by John Bowen
Co was nearly destroyed by fire Thursday afternoon
last. Several adjoining buildings considerably dam
aged. Two OF the fremen much injured by the
falling of cornce and gutter, that they survived the ac
cident but few hours.

The endorsements into which the house of
Lippincotts, of Philadelphia, was brought by the
heavy advances which it, in good faith. made on
certain quantities Of teas was matter OF notori-
ETY. throughout the country, and even became the
subject of paragraphs in the London and other
European Journals. The successful issue to which
it has brought its affairs, ought to be extensive
y known and we doubt not the communication
Of the fact will afford unmixed satisfaction to the
numerous friends and correspondents of this
house, both at home and abroad. During the past
year it has paid debts to the amount OF seven hun
dred thousand dollars; and it has very extern
sive solid capital remaining, quite as much as IT
can employ to advantage in business, in the pre-
sent state Of trade. An old merchant has told US
that he never knew of another house which, when
its scheme of commercial operations was in like
manner deranged, had been able to discharge so
large an amount of demands in so short period
Few commercial houses would indeed have sustain
ed such shock, and have brought their affairs to
such an issue, when deprived for so long time of
the use of great proportion of their circulating
capital. Ph't. dazeffe.

full articles.headline: EXTRACT OF A LETTER, DATED
full articles.article:
"The Woolen Bill is finally decided. The mo-
ton to lay it on the table, was carried by the cast
ino vote Of the vice president-to him therefore
are the manufacturers and the agriculturists to
place the disappointment of their hopes. The dis
ciplined opposition, from the earliest moment Of
the introduction of the bill, brought all their arts
to bear against it. BY proctastination and motions
Of recommitment; and Ir kramer, OF Pa was, to
our modification made TO p,av the part Of buffuon,
and speak against time r.-,sle,srs, lngham. Steven
son and others have much to answer for, for unit
ing against this measure which was SO much in
harmony with our past policy and 50 essential to
our prosperity. The time it seems, has arrived,
in this country, when all our great national mea-
sures are to be disposed Of as they shalt affect the
next Presidential election The south must be
propitiated by the Jackson men, even at the pros
traton of those measures from which we anticipated
so much and such lasting advantages. Messrs.
Stewart, Lawrence and Tell, have deserved well
Of our statc By their active participation in debate:
Others Of willing to engage in it if neces.
sary.


How long shall we be trammelled by the arts of
designing mcn. | was for Jackson, bat may public
confidence De withdrawn from Inc whenever con-
set to forego the interest of my constituents and
state, to elevate any individual to office. will
tell you, and MY state hereafter, the appeals that
were made to my Jackson prepossessions to induce





are open and verify believe now that General jack
son is mainly advocated by ambitious men, who
would sacrifice the cause of domestic industry and
Internal Improvement, it it should be thought ne
cessary for the election Of Mr. Calhoun; at the
termination of General Jackson's four years. do
hope and trust that all the papers favorable to these
great interests will correctly state these facts"


Philadelphia Press.


Washington. March 6.-Thc proceedings Of
the late Congress, and particularly of its Second
Session, are full of instruction. The grounds
upon which the Opposition are to take their stand
have been distinctly avowed Neutrality is no
longer lustifable. We must either sacrifice our
principles. or we must attach ourselves to one
party or the other. Avowing, from the moment
we established our press that we believed It to be
not only the right, but the duty, Of General Coy
ernment to prosecute Internal improvements and
to foster and encourage the Manufacturing inter
ests Of our Country, never can and never
will combine with party whose avowed prln
ciple is hostility to measures conducive to the gen
eral 'UeIfure, and such as will render us in time
war, at least for the necessaries of life, indepen
dent Of every nation upon the earth.--JournM

Atkinson has been apprehended for passing counterfeit
Gve dollar notes Of the Marine Bank. He succeeded in
passing Of them Friday, in the neghborhood Of
Howard and Lexington streets.


New York, March 5.
The Greeks-We have the satisfaction that
Mr.. p Miller of Vermont, who has been volunteer in
the Greek service for two years. arrived in this city last
evening He is full of ardor and enthusiasm for the
and win 60 Immediately the Agent of the Greek
Committee, in the ship Chancellor, which is loading
second ship will be despatched in short time in charge
Of Lieut.. Carpenter Of the Navy The Greek available
fund already received by the committee in this city, amounts
to $4,000 The subscriptions in kind amount TO upwards
Of 1000 lars So that there will be no difficulty
in sending two ships the purchases be
advantageousy made, and the ships can be freghted.


Neru York, March TO-
The Greek Supply Ship.-The elegant ship Chancellor
Capt. Baker. hauled out in the stream yesterday, and viii
probably sail to-day with provisions, &C. for the Greeks
Mr. Miller, of Vermont who three years in Greece
and eighteen montha active services goes out in the
sell He will have the charge of the supplies and pay at
enon their distribution The cargo said to be worth
about S18,0o0 including the freight and insurance. which
have been paid consists principally Of corn meal -four
rice and the like articles.
